title: Understanding Pelvic Pain
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Pelvic pain is felt in the lower abdomen between the belly button and groin. It can come from the reproductive organs, bladder, bowel, muscles, or connective tissue.
Pelvic pain is different from vaginal or vulval pain (which affects the external genitals).

content.title: Key Facts
content.description: Pelvic pain is a very common condition. Most causes are treatable. It can be acute or chronic.

items.title: Gynaecological Causes
items.content: Menstrual cramps (common before or during periods), Ovulation pain/mittelschmerz (sharp pain mid-cycle on one side), Endometriosis (womb lining tissue grows outside the uterus), Pelvic inflammatory disease/PID (infection of womb and surrounding tissues), Ectopic pregnancy (pregnancy outside the womb - medical emergency)

items.title: Urinary Causes
items.content: Cystitis/UTI (bladder infection or urinary tract infection), Interstitial cystitis (long-term bladder inflammation without clear cause), Urinary stones (crystals forming in kidneys or bladder)

items.title: Digestive Causes
items.content: Irritable bowel syndrome/IBS (pain, bloating, constipation or diarrhoea), Appendicitis (sudden pain in the lower right abdomen)

items: Have fever, nausea, or vomiting with pelvic pain
Notice unexpected vaginal bleeding or discharge
Have a known condition and pain suddenly worsens

content.title: Urgent Warning
content.description: Always get urgent help for sudden severe pain, fainting, or heavy bleeding.

content.value: Your doctor will assess your symptoms carefully using a combination of history-taking, examinations, and tests.

content.title: Early Investigation
content.description: Identifying the cause early helps your healthcare provider create the most effective treatment plan for you.

content.value: Chronic pelvic pain can affect mood, energy, and relationships. It's common to feel frustrated, anxious, or low.

content.title: Support Available
content.description: Talking to your doctor or asking for emotional support or counselling can help. You don't have to "just live with it" - help is available.

items.title: Use heat therapy
items.description: Warm baths or hot water bottles for cramps

items.title: Balanced diet
items.description: Eat well and drink plenty of water

items.title: Rest when needed
items.description: Take breaks when pain flares up

items: Pelvic pain is common and usually treatable
Many causes are not serious, but some need prompt attention
Early assessment can bring relief and peace of mind

content.title: We're Here to Help
content.description: If pelvic pain is affecting your life, book an appointment - we're here to help.
